nodes.text: Keeping a family calendar up to date
Patient
Getting a plan on creche logistics and sticking to it as that is the foundation for both myself and my husband's work schedules
My wife took career break to mind the kids at home rather than continue to use the creche as it was too expensive for creche fees
Openness but also flexibility with line-managers
Having someone who can be flexible to accomodate some of my overtime at work
We found sharing a child minder with neighbours or relatives good. But everyone is different
I rely on my parents who are retired and live nearby. Not really an achievement or secret but has helped defray a lot of the stress associated with having to work beyond the standard working day
Logistics, equaly sharing with partner and a support network
I'm not sure we have cracked it yet. We now dont look for long term solutions, just something that works for now!

I've tried everything- full time minder in home, part time minder, creche, after school care , au pair. Be open to a mix of all and be ok with it not being perfect. I also make it clear in work that I have to build flexibility into my working week or it just won't work. I also try not to feel guilty but that doesn't always work so well.
Bending over backwards to ensure the kids needs are met, aking for help, saying thank you and really valuing others time and support.
having one parent working close to home/school/creche
Constant communication and flexibility between myself and my wife in relation to who is on pick-up duty.
Flexibility
I'm lucky my husband's schedule is flexible
an amazing minder with granparents as back up

Putting them first before work and making sure my arrangements suit my family first and foremost as if it suits us and we are less stressed then I can be more committed to work. Using my free half day - guilt free - sorting myself and the house out so that I can spend all weekend with my family instead of cleaning, etc all weekend.

A great creche/childminder. Flexibility in work that if I have to run to school/ballet/school sports day! I can. I don't abuse it though and think that we all need to be responsible and respectful of our time - but also give that to others who work for us too
Flexible schedule
Not to panic.....
Husband with flexible working hours (3.5 days/wk), willing and able grandparents who put in one day per week each

Working from home and being here if needed. I know that won't work for everyone but my husband had a job that kept him outside Ireland for many weeks. I would have had to leave Accenture otherwise. Also working flexible hours - maybe working at night if need be so I can start at a later time in the am (when I was dropping them to school - now they get the bus)
Time Management and prioritisation of work (not everything needs to be done today), as well as communications of my schedule to ensure expectations of others are set
Ask for help from colleagues, family and friends. Help others also ... give and take.
work flexibility
used to pay 3/4 of salary for childminders, trustworthy ones
Planning and the flexibility afforded by Accenture when things don't go to plan!
having reliaable babysitter who is also prepared to do homework if needed.
Payment
Having a good creche and being able to pick my children up early two days per week, so they don't have to go to creche/afterschool 5 days per week
Both partners need to be able to be flexible - so one can step in when the other has a work challenge (especially a the last minute)
Marry well. Afraid I don't do my fair share
ADAPT CARE TO AGE OF CHILD
Cr√®che and time restrictions just doesn't work for Accenture working practices.
paying for the right support and not relying on family. Flexible work.
Equal responsiblity between myself and my husband & a small creche we love

pay the cost of a full time nanny or other carer, who are always there and will do the day to day responsibilities, and therefore do not have to rely on favours from friends and family and put them underpressure

I am adding a fair fw comments here and hope it is helpful as you combine with other inputs. Delighted to see this survey as it's not all about babies! For childmining at home with children 6+ a minder in early 20's works the best as we have seen. My son is now 13 and feels he doesn't need a minder but he does understand he needs someone to collect him, make dinner, and just to be there. My daughter who is 10 still gets the play / fun element with minder. Flexibility in work place environment is key. We bring kids to school daily. Up to this September it only required one of us - so we could split the week and start work at 9.30 if bringing kids to school. My son started secondary school in September and it requires us both going to 2 diffeent schools/areas. We have been able to share lifts with other families. I bring my daughter 3 days a week, her friends family bring her 2 days a week. My husband goes 1-4 times a week as we share with 2 other families. There is an adjustment at all stages. I want to make some further adjustments now that secondary has settled in as my son's schoold day is more like my work day yet my daughter is free in the afternoons and busy a few times a week with activities. Getting there!
in home childcare works best
Being very organised! expect the unexpected.. sickness etc just when you have million others things on the go.
I like the flexibility of using a creche and afterschool service. Also as I work from home childcare outside the home is a better option for us. That may change as the children get older.
Paying above the going rate
support from family
One parent at home works well for children
Hiring a good childminder
Having a back-up. When childminder is sick, I have the local creche to avail of. I make sure they are in the creche one day a week so to maintain a 'presence' there so in emergencies can call on them
Balance it with my wife. Support from Accenture to work outside of core working hours to compensate for late starts.

A childminder that treats the children like she would her own children. Also a childminder that is flexible with regard to being given a roster at the beginning of each month of the days that she is needed. In additon the wfh means I dont have to get the kids out too early in the morning to the childminder.

Having a husband who can be flexible too is key for me as we have no family based in Dublin to draw from for support. Childcare has varied hugely according to requirements at the time, we've had creche, child minders and au pairs over the years. So the biggest secret is flexiblity, flexibility and a good cleaner!
Open and reaslistic arrangements agreed with my spouse
still trying to crack this one
We used to have an au-pair when my kids were younger and it worked perfect
at the moment we are lucky that our family is supporting us (coming from different country to take care of kids) but that's only temporary. I am not sure yet how its going to work next year
Both parents being able to be flexible - understanding each others work schedule (both Accenture employees) - asking for help from family when required.

sharing the load between myself and my wife really helps. For example she may drop/collect 3 days and i'll do the other two. Or sometimes she will drop off and I will collect depending on work/social commitments on any given day.
Reconfiguring our expenses in order to have one parent home with the children all the time.
having the confidence to leave the office every day at 4.30pm (the all night working is not so great to make up for this though)
Flexible work hours

Avoiding feeling judged for whatever works. Being up front and non-apologetic about discussing fitting commitments with delivering really good work. Doing a phasing period with the creche where we sat with them for a week before leaving them there - have trusted them ever since as I got to see them . Shared responsibility with my husband for pickups/dropoffs (no mummy defaults!).
I think we've just been incredibly lucky!

We are lucky to have had the one child minder for the last 5 years. We have paid her above the odds, been really flexible on holidays and now she is part of the family. As a result, she is flexible on her side, without this, we would be goosed.
Multiple methods, au pair for older school going children & creche for toddler
Team work with my other half. Rollercoaster web site to advertise for new childcare. A good network of other mums.
